AT ALEXANDER CITY
CHRISTOPHER BLAINE MCGREGOR )
PLAINTIFF/RESPONDENT )
VS. ) CASE NO. DR-2023-900051.01
BRITTANY MICHELLE GILLILAND )
DEFENDANT/PETITIONER )
MOTION TO SET ASIDE ORDER GRANTING COURT-ORDERED HOLIDAY
VISITATION
Comes now the Plaintiff/Respondent, Christopher Blaine McGregor, by and through his
attorney of record, and files this Motion to Set Aside Order Granting Court-Ordered Holiday
Visitation and would state as follows:
1. That on November 6, 2024, this Court entered an Order as the result of a Contempt
filed by the Mother and a Counterclaim for Contempt filed by the Father, and after
conducting an in camera interview with the minor child, A.K.M., dob, 05/24/2012
that stated “Following the in camera interview, counsel for both Parties, along with
the Court, agreed that proceeding with the show cause hearing was not appropriate
at this time.” A copy of this Order is attached as Exhibit A.
2. That in paragraph five (5), it states: …after 10 joint reunification therapy sessions
with the Mother and A.K., or, if earlier, when the specialist believes that the
Mother and A.K. have established a relationship sufficient to make the previously
ordered visitation beneficial to A.K.”.
3. That in paragraph six (6) regarding weekly family dinners, which at a later date was
changed from Wednesday to Sunday, the Mother has failed to attend the twenty-six
(26) Sunday/Weekly dinners since January 8, 2025. These dinners were set out so
the Mother and A.K. could work towards a better relationship.
DOCUMENT 422
4. That the minor child does not, on her own accord, wish to visit with the Mother in the
Mother’s home due to past physical abuse by the Mother.
5. That in the transcript from the hearing on July 31, 2024, the minor child testified “I
just can’t stay alone with her. I don’t know what people don’t understand about
that. I can’t. I’m scared”.
6. That this Court entered an Order on April 14, 2025, that changed the Mother’s
visitation for the minor child B.M., dob, 05/10/2019, and further ordered the parties to
resume family dinners or lunches and work around A.K.M.’s activities. A copy of this
Order is attached as Exhibit “B”.
7. That the Mother could have given the “gifts” she has for A.K. at the family dinners if
she wanted her to have the gifts and wanted to build a bond and trust between herself
and the minor child, A.K.; however, she apparently chose not to do this.
8. That the Father too has been forced to incur attorney’s fees from the filing of this
motion, as he has not withheld visitation, as the Court has made it clear in prior
Orders that A.K. did not have to visit EXCEPT FOR THE WEEKLY/SUNDAY
DINNERS, which the mother does not attend on a regular basis.
9. Furthermore, the Father had to file a Motion for Contempt against the Mother this
date as she continued to refuse to sign the necessary documents to allow the minor
child, A.K, to continue counseling with the counselor she has been seeing and has
established a relationship with, even after this Court Ordered the child to continue
counseling. The counseling sessions are to help the minor child work towards a
better relationship with her Mother.
WHEREFORE, the premises considered, the Father requests this Court set aside the Order
entered this date granting the Mother’s Motion for Court-Ordered Holiday Visitation and further that the
Court Order the Mother to pay the Father’s Attorney Fees in the amount of $500.00 as the result of having
to file this Motion.
DOCUMENT 422
Respectfully submitted this the 6th day of November, 2025.
/s/Dianne James Davis
Dianne James Davis (DAV007)

ExL-,i
Order
This matter came before the Court for a show cause hearing on July 31, 2024,
concerning the Petition for Contempt filed by the Petitioner, Brittany Michelle Gilliland
(hereinafter "Mother"), and the Counterclaim for Contempt filed by the Respondent,
Christopher Blaine McGregor (hereinafter "Father"). These claims relate to alleged
violations of the Court's February 27, 2024, Final Decree of Divorce, specifically
regarding visitation with the Parties' minor child, A.K.
Prior to the hearing, the Parties agreed that the Court would conduct an in
camera interview with the minor child, A.K., whose relationship with the Mother and
Mother's visitation were central issues to the claims at hand. Present during the rn
camera interview and the hearing were the Parties' respective counsel, Barbara
Agricola and Matthew Holdren for the Mother, and Tom Young for the Father, as well as
reporter.
the court
)
The Court received testimony from the minor child concerning her current
relationship with the Mother and her reasons for not abiding by the court-ordered
visitation as laid out in the divorce decree. Following the rn camera interview, counsel
for both Parties, along with the Court, agreed that proceeding with the show cause
hearing was not appropriate at this time.
Accordingly, it is hereby ORDERED:
1. Continuation of Show Cause Hearing: The show cause hearing scheduled for July
31, 2024, is hereby continued generally, until further motion of either Party to set the
matter for a hearing after the court-ordered counseling begins.
2. Reunification Therapy: Effective immediately, Mother and A.K. shall begin attending
joint counseling/therapy sessions with Kelly Turner, a specialist in reunification therapy.
Upon the therapist submitting her reunification report to the Court, A.K. and Mother
shall continue to see Ms. Turner, provided no ethical conflicts exist, until Mother feels
that reunification counseling is no longer necessary.
3. CAG Joint Gounseling Sessions: At this time, the CAC is unavailable to conduct joint
DOCUMENT 423
DOCUMtsNT 66
counseling sessions. Once the CAC determines that joint counseling sessions would be
beneficial to the CAC counseling plan, Mother shall be permitted to attend any and all
sessions with A.K. that the CAC permits.
4. Gost of Counseling: The costs of any joint counseling sessions attended by Mother
and A.K. shall be paid in accordance with the terms for covered and uncovered medical
expenses as outlined in the divorce decree, in that any medical expenses not covered
by the Father's insurance for A.K. shall be divided equally between the Parties. lf
Father ever impedes upon these counseling sessions, causes A.K. to miss the
sessions, or allows A.K. to miss the sessions, for any reason other than emergency,
this will be considered willful contempt of this Court's order.
5. Reunification Specialist's Report: The Parties are directed to provide a copy of this
Order to the reunification specialist and A.K.'s counselor. The Court hereby requests
that the specialist submit a report to this Court and to counsel for both Parties after 10
joint reunification therapy sessions with the Mother and A.K., or, if earlier, when the
specialist believes that the Mother and A.K. have established a relationship sufficient to
make the previously ordered visitation beneficial to A.K.
6. Weekly Family Dinners: Beginning immediately, the Parties shall attend weekly
dinners together, including the Mother, Father, A.K., and the Parties' minor son. These
dinners shall take place every Wednesday evening at 6:30pm CST. These Wednesday
evening dinners shall take priority over all other events and shall only be cancelled in
case of emergency. If the Wednesday night dinner is cancelled, the Parties shall have a
"make-up" dinner the following day.
DONE this 6th day of November, 2024.
/s/ STEVEN R PERRYMAN
C!RCUIT JUDGE

TEMPORARY ORDER
This matter came before the court on the 3'd day of April 2025, on various motions. The
Plaintiff/Father, Christopher Blaine McGregor was present and represented by his attorney,
Dianne James Davis, and the Defendant/Mother, Brittany Michelle Gilliland was present and
represented by her attorney, Barbara H. Agricola. \tVhen it was called for a hearing, the parties
announced they had reached a temporary agreement. lt is hereby
:
1)
That the Mother's visits with the minor child, B.M. (DOB 5/10/19) shall be from
Friday after school until Monday when he is returned to school or to the Father.
Should the Mother not be available to pick the child up from school or after the
bell, she will inform the Fathet and he will get the child from school and have
him available for pick up by the mother.
2)
That the parties shall resume family dinners or lunches with both children in
Alex City on Sundays between the hours of 1:00 p.m. and 6:00 p.m. The
parties shall work around A.K.M.'s (DOB 5124112) activities should she have any
on those Sundays. The parties may mutually agree to any and all other times in
which to meet with the children.
3)
The Mother shall be entitled to Facetime each night with both children.
A status hearing, should the parties not be able to settle all pending motions, shall be
held on June 3, 2025, at 1:00 p.m. A ruling on all pending motions are reserved untilJune 3,
2025.
DONE this 14th day of April, 2025.
